==Windows 8 and Windows Server 8==
==Windows 8 and Windows Server 8==
[[File:Windows 8 Developer Preview Start Screen.png||thumb|Windows 8 screenshot]]
[[File:Windows 8 Developer Preview Start Screen.png||thumb|Windows 8 screenshot]]
â
[[File:Windows To Go USB Flash Drive.png|thumb|Bootable [[Windows To Go]] USB flash drive, upcoming Windows 8 feature|link=Windows To Go]]
 
{{Main|Windows 8}}
{{Main|Windows 8}}
Windows 8 is the upcoming version of Microsoft Windows, expected to be released in 2012.It will be the last 32 bit OS from Microsoft for home users. It was first mentioned at the 2011 [[Consumer Electronics Show]] in Las Vegas, where Microsoft announced that it would include support for system-on-a-chip and mobile [[ARM architecture|ARM processors]]. On 1 June 2011, Microsoft officially unveiled the operating system at Computex 2011. The redesigned user interface in this release was designed to accommodate a variety of devices and screen sizes, in a departure from the previous Windows focus on personal computers.<ref>[http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2011/jun11/06-01corporatenews.aspx Previewing 'Windows 8': Article by Julie Larson-Green, corporate vice president, Windows Experience<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> On the Building Windows 8 blog, it was announced that a computer running Windows 8 can boot up much faster than Windows 7.<ref name="Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times">{{cite web | url=http://www.winsupersite.com/blog/supersite-blog-39/windows8/microsoft-touts-incredible-windows-8-boot-times-140515 | title=Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times | publisher=Penton Media | accessdate=September 09, 2011 | author=Thurott, Paul}}</ref> New features also include [[USB 3.0]] support, the Windows App Store, the ability to run from USB drives with [[Windows To Go]], and others.
Windows 8 is the upcoming version of Microsoft Windows, expected to be released in 2012.It will be the last 32 bit OS from Microsoft for home users. It was first mentioned at the 2011 [[Consumer Electronics Show]] in Las Vegas, where Microsoft announced that it would include support for system-on-a-chip and mobile [[ARM architecture|ARM processors]]. On 1 June 2011, Microsoft officially unveiled the operating system at Computex 2011. The redesigned user interface in this release was designed to accommodate a variety of devices and screen sizes, in a departure from the previous Windows focus on personal computers.<ref>[http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2011/jun11/06-01corporatenews.aspx Previewing 'Windows 8': Article by Julie Larson-Green, corporate vice president, Windows Experience<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> On the Building Windows 8 blog, it was announced that a computer running Windows 8 can boot up much faster than Windows 7.<ref name="Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times">{{cite web | url=http://www.winsupersite.com/blog/supersite-blog-39/windows8/microsoft-touts-incredible-windows-8-boot-times-140515 | title=Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times | publisher=Penton Media | accessdate=September 09, 2011 | author=Thurott, Paul}}</ref> New features also include [[USB 3.0]] support, the Windows App Store, the ability to run from USB drives with [[Windows To Go]], and others.
